comments.raw_text: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; de; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; de; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 When requesting my test site, an external url is loaded, which exists only as src inside an IMG "tag" in a JS variable Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. The test file must have at least 4 external loaded script files - the existence doesn´t care 2. HTML code must be assigned to a JS variable. I used the following (the source tag doesn´t have quotes, because FF use the quotes at request time too): var interpretedHTML = ""; 3. The JS part must have a size of at least 96k. I filled this after the above assignment with: /* waste waste waste ...tbc... */ 4. call the page Actual Results: "Fiddler" prints an opening socket to "the-image-of-this-hoste-areloaded.com" with the contents "GET /image.png HTTP/1.1" (notice my IMG src) Expected Results: No URL request Maybe other contents as images can be used. We had the problem on a production site of an application and I striped down the code to this testcase
comments.text: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; de; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; de; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 When requesting my test site, an external url is loaded, which exists only as src inside an IMG "tag" in a JS variable Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. The test file must have at least 4 external loaded script files - the existence doesn´t care 2. HTML code must be assigned to a JS variable. I used the following (the source tag doesn´t have quotes, because FF use the quotes at request time too): var interpretedHTML = ""; 3. The JS part must have a size of at least 96k. I filled this after the above assignment with: /* waste waste waste ...tbc... */ 4. call the page Actual Results: "Fiddler" prints an opening socket to "the-image-of-this-hoste-areloaded.com" with the contents "GET /image.png HTTP/1.1" (notice my IMG src) Expected Results: No URL request Maybe other contents as images can be used. We had the problem on a production site of an application and I striped down the code to this testcase

comments.text: This is likely not going to be fixed in 3.6.x, if this has existed for some time - and will just be case of needing to upgrade to Firefox 4 when it is released.
